Order of the Sun Soul

The Sun Soul monks follow a monastic tradition that they believe has its roots in the ancient empire of Netheril. In their philosophy, living things harbor a fragment of the sun's mystic essence within them. Just as the body has a shadow, so too does the spirit have a light. To get in touch with their internal light, Sun Soul monks follow a strict code of ascetic conduct called the Precepts of Incandescence: to seek physical perfection, to seek spiritual virtue, to shine light into darkness.
Each Abbot and Abbess are the head of their own monastery.

Monastic Discipline
By completing missions and rising through the ranks of the order, you'll gradually gain traits that are associated to the order's ethos.
Perfect Self
By training along the masters of your monastic order, you'll gradually push yourself towards peak performance of body and mind. Characters with levels in the monk class might reach better results.
Enables a decision in the §YIntrigue§! menu, allowing you to train along the masters of your monastic order.
Perfection manifests in many different ways. You learned that you should strive to keep your body and belongings clean and beautiful.
The masters of the order have had enough with your lack of grooming and personal hygiene. They are making sure you take care of yourself, or else!
No body is perfect without a honed mind at the helm. Countless hours of meditation in extreme conditions are bestowing great mental clarity upon you.

Using your brain is such a strenuous activity for you, that you often end up acting without thinking. The masters of the order are having none of that, and are forcing you to learn some mental discipline.
Vassalize the Sun Soul
As an high ranking member of the Order of the Sun Soul and as a powerful ruler, you can bring the order into your realm as a vassal.

Sometimes, I get this nice, pleasant, irrational feeling when I see other people happy. I know I shouldn't let it get to me...it's just a weak, pathetic natural instinct, ill suited to a merciless killer such as myself. Maybe I could be a little kinder to those close to me, in secret...to satisfy the urge?
No one needs to know.
This is how they get to you. No mercy.
It worked. A little bit of kindness to those most close to me, and I could just go back to ignore everyone else. As I should.
Finally.
This is just embarassing. One act of kindness led to another, and I find myself giggling and smiling like an idiot. This is not who I am!
Shameful.
Those irrational feelings of kindness are finally gone, and my heart is as stony and cold as it's supposed to be. I'll never let my emotions take control of me ever again.
Power is the only thing that matters.

This isn't good...today, the young daughter of a farmer I recently executed for tax evasion came to court. Her genuine desperation moved me deeply, and I couldn't hold back tears...right in front of all my courtiers.
It's just so sad!

When those I believe to be guilty somehow manage to escape punishment, I get angry. I know that true justice requires solid proof, but it would so much easier to forge a little bit of evidence here and there...at least when the culprit obviously deserves it!
Yes. The truly despicable deserve no quarter.
No! The legal system is fair, and it works.
With just the slightest bit of manipulation and fabrication, no criminal can escape a guilty verdict. When backed into a corner, they all end up confessing, anyway, so I know I'm right!
That was wise of me.
This is so horrible. When my fabricated evidence was effortlessly countered by an ironclad alibi, I felt so ashamed of myself...
How could I be so wrong?
Oh Lady Justice, how could I ever doubt you? Proving a culprit's guilt with a fair trial, without cheating, is so satisfying!
I AM the law!
Laws are worthless, aren't they? As another criminal triumphally strides out of our courtroom, I am left to wonder that perhaps there is no justice in this world.
I'll take justice into my own hands.

column2: Order of the Long Death

The Order of the Long Death is a monastic order devoted to understanding every aspect related to the process of dying and the nature of death itself. They care little for the afterlife, and seek no deeper understanding of a soul's place in the greater cosmology, but rather the effects of death on intelligent beings and the achievement of 'perfect death'. They see this as the ultimate offering they could bestow upon any being who is deemed truly ready.
Each Abbot and Abbess is the head of their own monastery.
